intro: Sisyrinchium dasyspathum subsp. dasyspathum, commonly known as the narrowleaf blue-eyed grass, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the family Poaceae, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and narrow leaves. The plant produces small, blue to purple flowers clustered in spikelets, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Its ornamental value and ability to tolerate drought make it a desirable plant for native gardens.
